												absolutely one of the most bone chilling gaming experiences i've had the pleasure of undergoing. if you let yourself get immersed, or worse, comfortable, you will be in for the most pleasantly unpleasant 10 hours of your game life. of course, 90s textures can only do so much for the horror atmosphere, which is why i recommend graphical enhancement mods like SHTUP, which can be found on the system shock forum (first result on google) and also mods for weapon models and the like. content:
Posted: August 12, 2015
~ Your flesh is an insult to the perfection of the digital. ~You've probably heard it by now, but System Shock 2 can basically be described best as "RPG BioShock set in space". But considering SS2 was first it basically means BioShock is "FPS System Shock 2 set under the sea". But I digress. SS2 takes place on the Von Braun, a spaceship that's surrounded by the darkness of space. After training for four years (or four minutes in our lives) you wake up on the Von Braun. If that's not enough to feel claustrophobic, early on you also find out something mysteriously and equally terrifying had happened on the ship on your absence. Guided by another survivor you start from the bottom of the ship and you work yourself to the top to uncover the ship's secrets. No marks, no hints, you're mostly on your own and there's little to no holdings hands (as it should be). Gameplay wise it holds up great, the combat is deep, the pacing is good, and there may be some dated animations here and there, but nothing too serious. Combat can be experienced as a little less flexible than BioShock for example, but that's because you're "stuck" with your current build, due to the skill points you invested in it, which means you can't drastically change your play style in SS2, which was possible in BioShock. But on the other hand, it means the replay value is higher in SS2.This is the first time I played this 16 year old game and I'd definitely recommend this for other people who like a good RPG dripping with atmosphere that doesn't hold your hands, like most of the games nowadays.+ An isolated feeling, claustrophobic, drips with atmosphere.+ Main antagonist is very sinister and interesting, good story.+ Optional audio logs you can find add to the atmosphere.+ Expansive gameplay with lots of options to suit your play style. + Little to no holding hands. There are no markers of any sorts.-/+ - No subtitles. Which isn't a big problem, even for non-native English speakers like me, but sometimes there's a lot of background noise in-game which makes it a little hard to hear. But there's a log system that you can use to reread most of the dialogues and diaries.- Some (not all) songs are way too "bombastic' and sound somewhat out of place, they don't have that feeling of isolation and claustrophobia to begin with. - Some enemies, at least at first, spawn very quickly, which can lead to some frustration. Especially in the beginning when you're not exactly full on Medical and Psi hypos.- The final boss battle ends on a ridiculous and downright out-of-place note that may leave you with somewhat of a sour taste in your mouth. "Nah." The final cut scene after that is good though.

Posted: May 15, 2016
												This might be the best game I've ever played, seriously.After no luck with the original Deus Ex from the fact I just couldn't get into it (Human Revolution is my favorite game), I was rather jaded and cynical. Having loved Bioshock 1 and 2 equally and the love I have for the dead space franchise (even though it's annoyingly console oriented), I thought "eh it's only like £1 on♥♥♥♥♥quot;. The major dissapointment of Bioshock: Infinite, granted I only played on it on console, made me want to explore the roots of two of my favorite games. I did research into Irrational Games throughout the late 90's and thinking of those programmers, sound engineers and art designers crammed into a tiny room creating this gave me a whole new appreciation for video game creation.So on starting the game, I found all the different elements confusing at first (as with a lot of games), but immediately started noticing the similarities between bioshock and SS2:  - PSI = EVE - Cybernetic Modules = ADAM - Security Codes - Wrench - and much more.Given that this game was created barely a year after I was born, it has aged phenominally well and feels like a modern AAA title just with worse graphics. Also SHODAN is now my favorite villian of all time, maniny due to the creepy apperance and voice(s). The Many is also a VERY creepy villian and ALMOST tops SHODAN and how I noticed the similarities between The Many and The Corruption.I didn't feel as if playing the first game was nessasary and I think even after playing this I would find it just too dated. I didn't however, use any additional mods or graphical enhancements and played on easy because I'm bad :P. I can't wait to play the user created levels.So in summary, this game is near perfect and DO NOT EVEN HESITATE to buy it, seriously. The Many flesh levels and the rather underwhelming boss fight were the ONLY bad things (I actually liked the ending, made me chuckle). And then we have news that System Shock 3 in development and Terri Brosius is again voicing SHODAN which is the best news ever. I feel as if this game was made for me, as do so many others.-----98/100 - a.k.a BUY IT!

												SS2 needs no introduction, its one of those games which took the FPS/RPG hybrid genre forward. This is a game which is completely ahead of its time by all means, it has a powerful story, an awesome pacing, well crafted narration and the gameplay is so unique there are tonns of options you can use while playing. These options are basically character development, you have a deep system of Stats, Skills and Attributes just like an RPG game and thus adds up to the replaybility. Even weapons come in variety and you have to stick to a specific class of weapons, energy based, bullet based, explosive, melee or even your cybernetic powers like telekinesis and stuff. There is a lot of exploration, you scavenge the environment for ammo, health and other things to survive, the premis of the game speaks for itself, story comes to you by means of PDF's and audiologs found all around the area. The story is suspense and as it unfolds, it drops your jaw.The atmosphere is thick and the musical score if composed by non other than the pioneer Eric brosius. This game comes from the same people who later on developed Bioshock and Bioshock Infinite, this is Ken Levines first Master Piece...Im not a fan boy but i can confidently say that SS2 does a lot many things much better than Bioshock.If you like Cyberpunk, RPG, FPS or even if you liked the first Deus EX, YOU HAVE TO PLAY THIS GAME...

content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
												My personality- I'm a player who prides himself in trying to experience a game as the makers had originally intended. This includes setting the difficulty in most games to a high enough level that it requires me to put thought into how I invest my limited resources, yet not so difficult that I'm trying to save precious ammo (or health, etc) by fighting a single fight only to run back to the last point of safety to re-group. I also appreciate (somewhat) linear narrative games with in depth plots and character building...REVIEW - I found this game extremely enjoyable for almost it's whole duration. The plot was something I could imerse myself into and get hooked. The character depth was slightly limited (with respect to some of the newer games that have come out) but not so much that it felt like it lacked something. Putting myself back into the year this game was released, I would have indeed called it revolutionary. A great game overall.(SPOILERS) However...I was extremely irritated by one HUGE miss... throughout the game, the choices I made left it literally impossible to defeat the final boss. I had chosen to invest my point in skill other than hacking, which when it came time to fight SHODAN without ICE-picks it was literally impossible to defeat her. I did not find this out till later. I spent a long time fighting her, intrigued and perplexed by the difficulty, I kept telling myself that there was something I'm missing. This increased my anticipation for the moment when I finally figured it out. Eventually I explored what seemed like every option. I resorted, to what I consider my LAST resort, I looked up how to defeat her online. If any of you share my personality, you know how difficult a choice this was. What I discovered was that, in fact, I was doing all the right things, but because of my choices ealier in the game, I could not finish the game. This left me irritated and frustrated. In my opinion one of the best things about a game is the nostalgic feeling that you get when you think about a game that you had finished awhile back. The final boss SHODAN removed this feeling from this game for me entirely. My suggestion... if you really want to experience this game as the revolutionary and awesome game that it truly was... Put at least one point into Hacking!If you take my advice you will experience a great game, unfortunately my own was ruined by a design miss on the developer's part.

Posted: July 22, 2016
												If you're a gamer who needs cutting-edge graphics to make a game worthwhile...take a pass on this one.  But to every one else...what are you waiting for?System Shock 2 was (and IS) a crossroads in gaming history.  It's the first true 'hybrid'...combination of horror, survival, RPG, FPS, and story-driven actioner.  PLUS it's got the single greatest 'reveal' in gaming history!  (NOTE - remember that it's 17 years old...if you've been playing that long, you'll remember that games didn't hold a lot of surprises back then.)The mechanics and inventory management aspects are a bit clunky, but they're easily doable once you get into the swing of it.  And unlike a lot of more recent RPG games, you absolutely CAN NOT max all skills, particularly if you go with the hardest settings.  Which means that, on the 'Impossible' rank, you have to be very careful about where you spend your upgrade points.  If you're smart, you may be able to max the one skill that saves your life.First timers may find it a bit of a cliche, but you have to remember...this is the game that created those cliches.  Classic games like Bioshock and Deus Ex were spawned from System Shock 2...so if you are a fan of those games, you owe it to yourself to experience the grandfather of them all.  But maybe I'm just an old fart who loves the evolution of games...decide for yourself.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												Are you the kind of gamer who almost exclusively enjoys super-fast first-person games in which you race about at lightning speed, effortlessly shooting hundreds and thousands of enemies with the aid of a seemingly inexhaustible supply of ammo loaded into a vast array of super-duper-mega-weapons which never jam and are capable of obliterating almost an entire herd of beasties in a single mouse-click?  Then you may well enjoy the Serious Sam games...and should probably give THIS one a wide ♥♥♥♥in' berth.   System Shock 2 is one HARD sonofa♥♥♥♥♥ of a game.  At first I thought it might just be me - as it so often is - but a quick chat to a Steam friend who's much more of a "natural" at games than yours truly confirmed that not only had he found it challenging, he had in fact found it SO frigging difficult that he just threw in the towel altogether, before the match had even officially begun.  This game is NOT from the user-friendly era which we're so used to nowadays, in which kind-hearted games essentially hold your hand for the entirety of the journey, like an oh-so-generous "self-help" coach who won't let you give up, no matter how hard times might get.  This game is more akin to a brutish boot-camp commandant, who just can't wait to push your worthless face down into the mud one more time, just in case you weren't suitably humiliated by the first ninety-nine times.  In short, this game DOES NOT PLAY NICE.  But for the most part, it does at least play FAIR...unlike, say, the recent Slender: The Arrival, a game whose difficulty can be mostly attributed to rather dubious design and execution.  Whereas System Shock 2, for all its frustration-inducing mean-spiritedness, is in fact an EXCEPTIONALLY well-designed and executed piece of work.  But a game for the weak-hearted or impatient it most certainly is not.   Weapons jam and need to be repaired, frequently.  There's♥♥♥♥♥♥all healing, certainly in the earlier stages.  And the maps, one of my few genuine "complaints" about the game, almost require a degree in Interstellar Architecture to follow.  To make matters trickier, there aren't any arrows helpfully pointing you in the "right" direction at all times, and it's basically up to you (or the always-generous Google) to work out just what the hell all those items you keep picking up actually do (and which ones you should bother to keep, when your limited Inventory space inevitably fills up almost every time you search a new area...hell, it took me a while to realise that all the pot plants I'd collected were basically extraneous)!  And what about all those different skills you can choose to spend your all-too-precious "cybermodules" on..."What the hell do I need a "Research" skill for, you crazy, crazy game", I hear you cry?!  Well, the simplest answer to that question is, "That all depends on HOW you want to play the game."  Put another way:  Don't expect to explore all the possibilities System Shock 2 has to offer on the first play-through.  I personally didn't even TOUCH any of the "Psi" attributes, and only barely scratched the surface of all that the "Tech" stream of abilities has to offer.  (For all the dumb♥♥♥♥♥people out there, like me, maybe just stick to being a half-decent fighter to begin with...doesn't take a genius to work out what a gun is for, while the worthiness of the "Hack" skill, for example, may be a tad more obscure at the outset.)   So okay, I get it, it's hard and it's complicated, but is it actually any GOOD?  Well, one need only look at its LEGACY to see how important and influential this game has been.  Unfortunately for System Shock 2, it appears to have been released at much the same time as a certain tiny little piece of gaming called Half Life, and it would appear that that game and its subsequent franchise stole much of SS2's thunder.  But have you also heard of a series called the Bioshock games?  Well, this is the "spiritual predecessor", designed by much the same people.  You can also spot the influence this game has had on, say, the Dead Space and F.E.A.R. franchises from several small galaxies away.  The more "RPG"-ish aspects of Borderlands, et al, would also appear to owe something of a debt herein, what with the space-age vending machines you can use to purchase items and ammo and healing and what-not from.    A true trail-blazer of a game indeed.  But how do the graphics and sound stack up against modern games, then?  Well...okay, the graphics have dated a little.  But they're more than made up for by some of the most imaginative and downright disturbing sound design in VIDEO GAME HISTORY.  It's nothing less than a work of art, ya'll.  And the story, while suffering from the limitations which are unavoidable when you're talking about a game where you basically traverse large distances while killing lots and lots of "baddies", is about as good as you can reasonably ask such things to be.   Look, it's not a completely "perfect" game.  As well as the aforementioned maps, there's other frustrations to be overcome and/or tolerated, such as the incredibly irritating tendency for a completely random "wandering" enemy to waltz into the room in which you thought you might finally have sufficient breathing space to listen to that "PDA" you've been carrying for the past several minutes.  You're gonna have to learn to do things like bring up the Inventory screen and heal yourself WHILST RUNNING down a corridor avoiding enemy fire.  And most of all, you're gonna learn to Save just about every time you pick up a new item or defeat a fresh enemy.  But with a little patience and just a teeny tiny bit of skill - Lord knows, I have precious little of the latter - you might actually manage to defeat the completely insane HAL - whoops, slight slip there, make that SHODAN - and emerge triumphant in a world ruled over by rampant technology.  Sounds like a nice change from your "real life", day-to-day existence, don't it?    Highly recommended to anyone who enjoys a not-entirely-mindless "shooter", and an absolute must-play for anyone with an interest in the history of such games.  Doom, Quake, Half-Life, THIS...that's just about the list, I believe.  I guess I should probably play System Shock 1 some time, too...dang, no rest for the wicked...Verdict: 9.5/10.

												Damn good game.  The character graphics are a little dated, but the environment itself has aged spectacularly.  SHODAN is particularly memorable and the game hits a nice mix of horror, difficulty, and survivability.  There's a lot of the Bioshock series' gameplay in this (for those of you who played those before this), which makes sense since the people who made System Shock 2 went on to create the BIoshock games. It's perfectly possible to find yourself in a nearly unwinnable situation - don't waste ammunition, be sure to pick up ammo from everywhere you can, and learn to love the melee weapons.All in all, well worth the purchase price, and a classic.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2014
												System Shock 2 is a game that a lot of modern shooters try and fail to emulate, because there was a cult classic love to it that wasn't because of any overused horror trope or any trendy game mechanic. No, the game actually broke from all of the standards by incorporating RPG elements along with its FPS style. You'll hear some people complain about the inventory system. Others will be hung up on the late-nineties graphics (which are close to those of the original Half-Life). I even have one friend who stopped playing simply because he couldn't take one of the enemies seriously.Don't listen to these people who get hung up on the small stuff, and don't be surprised by the difficulty that the game presents you. System Shock 2 was made back when games weren't willing to sacrifice quality just to get you to the ending credits and the obligatory sequel teaser trailer. It's a game that makes you consistently and intelligently plan your way through in order to survive, let alone make progress, aboard the Von Braun. There are multiple ways to play the game, with different types of weapons, and many skills and strengths to invest in. This means extreme replay value, and ensures that you won't get bored quickly.My advice to you is to pick up this game for yourself and make your own opinion. If you come into it with a modern bias, you might not give yourself a chance to enjoy it. Just install it, play it, and see where it takes you.And my biggest tip? For the first time through, put yourself on Away, log off of your communication devices and programs (Skype, AIM, et al.), and play System Shock 2 alone. The experience alone will leave you wanting more.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
 Some heavy Spoilers System Shock 2 is a First-Person RPG Survival Horror where you play as Soldier G65434-2, commonly known as "Goggles", the almost silent main protagonist who is without much development so it's easier for the player to project themselves as the character who signed up to work at the UNN Rickenbacker, a military space vessel that accompanies a FTL(faster than light) starship known as the Von Braun.The player gets to choose which military branch they'd like to select which ultimately comes down to which "class" you'd like to pick.The O.S.A, which helps you focus on psionic abilities which resembles "magic" where you'd have a wide variety of abilities ranging from firing energy to damage enemies, pulling items that would be otherwise unobtainable, to even healing yourself when you're low on health.The Marines, that focuses on combat granting you early access to some weapons with a little of utility stats so you don't risk being a brainless brute.And finally the Navy, a class that has more focus on hacking, repairing and access to minor weaponry so you're not completely defenseless. There are tons of terminals to hack and your weapons degrade incredibly fast so the Navy has a lot of useful utilities.With that said the classes do not limit you to types of weapons or abilities including hacking and repairing as you can increase your stats, so choosing a starter class will have very little impact on your overall gameplay. They matter a bit more but much akin to how Dark Souls handles its classes.From the games events eventually you'll find yourself being awoken in a cryo-tube on the Von Braun by some disturbances and contacted by a woman called Dr. Janice Polito who will guide you through the starship's decks, now infected by beings known as The Many, who will also telepathically persuade you to become a part of their mass and along the way you will begin to question Dr. Janice Polito's intentions as she talks down to you as if she's a goddess and you're just a mere  insect .The starship has all dangerous monstrosities ranging from The Many's undead-like abominations that hunt you and not only that it seems like the whole starship wants you dead as even the electronics turn against you. The scarce amount of supplies and the unrelenting difficulty makes you dread what's around the corner as you'll be balled up in a room questioning yourself if you want to use the round of bullets you recently picked up whilst hearing the moans of the grotesque creature in the other room telling you that he's "Sorry.".The graphics are very dated seeing as the game was released in 1999 but the excellent audio compensates and helps keeps you immersed at all times ranging from the enemies speaking to you or themselves and the audio of your crew member's logs that help you understand their twisted experiences on the ship and sometimes include their inevitable demise.The game has a co-op option so you can experience the horrors with up to 3 other friends but be prepared to save often before you load new zones as someone may not be able to make it through. Luckily the game is old and even on dated systems you're able to load it back up in less than half a minute. Unless you're keeping a light mood or goofing around, the experience of survival horror will remain there as you need to now manage the divided scarce supplies but with the advantage of having more hands with more skills to help you battle through the hordes.Lengthwise the game is very long with little backtracking, without exploring everything my first time completing it took me 14 hours on Normal difficulty and for what it costs if you like Horrors and First-Person RPGs then it's a must buy.Personally this is the best survival horror game made to this date and one of the better games made and is absolutely recommended."I hope you enjoyed your little rebellion, irritant. But remember, what SHODAN gives she is more than able to take away."

content:
Posted: May 14, 2013
												The awards and ratings don't lie, this is one of those games that you are required to have played to be considered a true gamer. System Shock 2 is a HUGE cult classic, and if I was the kind of person who easily picked favorites, this would have a good chance of being it. If you don't want to read my entire comment here, the summary is at the bottom.The most important thing about this game can be summed up in one word, and that is: atmosphere. This game has a dark Drum & Bass soundtrack, and like all old game soundtracks, it's perfectly suited for the game. It adds to the game's horror atmosphere, which has it's strength in anticipation rather than jump scares. Those of you who have played Dead Space, it draws quite a bit from System Shock 2. A horror game on a derelict ship invaded by strange creatures, with logs of the dead giving you an idea of what happened. System Shock 2 invented that and more.As Yahtzee said, this is an Action RPG, not an action game with RPG elements. The character customization has a huge effect on your character, and you have to build him carefully. Screw it up, and you'll find yourself in a pretty bad situation, sometimes unable to progress if you really botched it. The higher the difficulty, the more unforgiving that system is, though later game it isn't as bad(in my experience).So in short, System Shock 2 is a highly atmospheric, creepy, pioneering, often unforgiving RPG, that is probably one of the best games I've ever played. It's WELL worth over twice it's price, there's no excuse for you to not play it. If you want to be seen as a true gamer and not a stereotypical COD fanboy, or if you just want to experience one of the best games out there, then you may want to add this game to your collection of things you've played. No matter how advanced graphics get today, just like Doom, Quake, Unreal and Deus Ex, System Shock 2 is one of those games that left its mark on gaming, and will never go away.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
												I did not expect a game from 1999 to be very scary. I mean, the engine couldn't be too powerful, how scary could they make it?Very.Many games come with the recommendation "take a break between every hour of play", but this is the only game where I've actually done that. Although this game does have the occasional jump scare (turning a corner in to a previously empty hall and there's a monster RIGHT THERE), most of the terror is of the slow, suspenseful kind, where you're sitting on the edge of your seat, are quietly mumbling "moommmyyy" and wish that blasted light in your ceiling fan didn't flicker ominously.This game has aged wonderfully, and is well worth the price - especially if you can pick it up on a sale!However, there are some caveats. There are five kinds of people that should not get this game:1: Graphics snobs. This is an old game. Don't go in to it expecting Crysis.2: People with weak hearts.3: People that like being able to sleep at night.4: Small children (This should be self explanatory, but y' never know.)5: People absolutely incapable of forward planning. No respecs in this game (Although it does allow for save-scumming if you feel like it.)If you don't fall under those categories, and you like the idea of scrambling for survival in a spaceship infested with horrors-that-cannot-be-more-specifically-described-because-it-would-ruin-the-plot, then get this game.Or put it on your wishlist and wait for a Sale. You already have a huge backlog of games already (we all do!), and this game gets massively discounted during Steam Sales.

Posted: January 23, 2016
												SS2 is a superb game, even if you slept on it and are new to the series in 2016, like me. The intriciate storytelling, immersive level design, and long length bring back memories from the golden age of PC gaming: late 90s. If you are looking for something on the scale of Half Life, but with a more scifi feel, this is the game for you. Off the bat I have to say yes, you have to play this game with graphical and gameplay mods. I would recommend installing them right away, because the vanilla game is almost 20 years old. However, the mods are very easy to install using BMM, its about as intuitive as the nexus mod manager. There is a good SS2 community online with a recommended mod setup. I followed their guidelines and the game looked great honestly. The best parts about the game:- Wonderful story with great voice acting and music. Once you start you have to finish.- With graphical overhaul mods the game looks pretty good and (energy) weapons are very stylish- In this day and age of AAA flops and DLC on disc, this game delivers great value. Grab it on sale and you're set. Some cons:- Honestly, I found the game difficult at first coming in with no background. Sometimes I had to use console. However, I was really engrossed by the story and it didn't bother me after a while- The combat is dated if you're coming from recent PC games. It's still fun but not mindblowing in any way. However it does hold up well, no doubt about it- Some of the menus have small printOverall a great game for the price. I think every gamer who appreciates a timeless story and wants to see the critical predecessors to modern RPG games should check this one out.

Posted: December 3, 2014
												What is it with Sci Fi Horror set in space and Hydroponics deck being the most terrifying thing in the entire game? I don't know how, but this game, despite the fact that it hasn't aged well at all in the graphics department, creates such an amazing atmosphere and really sets the tone in an exemplary way. You play a guy with absolutely no fashion sense (jumpsuit and cybernetically implanted goggles make him look like Adam Jensen going through his goth phase) on his quest to find out just what went wrong on the Von Braun, which has seemingly been taken over by worm people and overly friendly robots who blow up in your face, spoiler alert. Despite the sometimes dodgy voice acting and the pretty awful movement controls (in my opinion, but then again almost all games from this period controlled like♥♥♥♥♥♥, this game is a great RPG, and one of the few in recent memory that has a fairly rich and detailed mythos embedded into the game itself. We don't get enough good Sci-Fi/Cyberpunk Action RPG's, in my opinion, and despite the fact that this is a precursor to this genre, it is still one of the best in terms of atmosphere, story and world building. I heartily reccomend this game to any fans of the genre. Speaking as a person who doesn't have nostalgia goggles on (many people seem to in the review section, and with good reason), I can safely say that this game still holds up in quite a few respects all these years on. Notstalgia usually makes people think of something that may have been ok-ish as the best thing since sliced bread, but what happens when it is something truly great for its time?

However, I was really engrossed by the story and it didn't bother me after a while- The combat is dated if you're coming from recent PC games. It's still fun but not mindblowing in any way. However it does hold up well, no doubt about it- Some of the menus have small printOverall a great game for the price. I think every gamer who appreciates a timeless story and wants to see the critical predecessors to modern RPG games should check this one out.

												First of all, any PC gamer worth his salt already knows this is a masterpiece of sci-fi horror FPSRPG, it's a beast of a game and a cult classic. If you didn't know, that should be enough to convince you, but let me re-iterate it's historical importance and worthiness.This is the game that not only inspired Bioshock, but everything else like it since (that includes anything from Fallout 3/NV to TES: Morrowind/Oblivion/Skyrim to Borderlands). Here's the basic formula: they took an FPS, added actual RPG elements, a real story, plus a horror atmosphere mixed with a sci-fi theme, and basically created a new genre. That's pretty significant, so if you've played Bioshock and haven't played this, you really should be ashamed of yourself... Fortunately for you, all hope is not lost as SS2 is now available on Steam and fixed to run on modern rigs so you may yet redeem yourself by playing it. Yay!A word of advice, though SS2 looks and sounds as old as it is, there are excellent texture/model/sound replacement mods available and they work fine with the Steam version. Despite all that, it still feels and plays better than most games of the genre today and remains a very special and highly memorable gaming experience nonetheless.Let me assure you that if I could have but one single wish answered by the Gods of Gaming it would be for a proper, actual sequel. But for some stupid reason, the license rights are of course tied up in limbo thanks to the absolutely rificulous bureaucratic state of the world, and so us poor gamers are left to suffer without it.Game like it was 1999!

content:
Posted: March 23, 2015
												This game needs no introduction. It's regarded as one of the best games for PC ever made, as well as one of the best for its genre... and it is wholly deserving of all its praise. System Shock 2 is a game that defies any real review, to do so would to really spoil the experience. It needs to be played to understand why it is so good, and that is what playing it is: an experience.The game is a rare example of design, gameplay, aesthetic, atmosphere, and presentation all working in near perfect harmony to deliver an engrossing experience that pulls you in and keeps you going until the final hours are passed. The RPG elements are almost completely free form, allowing you to build your character in almost any way you like focusing on what you want as you want it (though in the early game you'll do well to focus on your initial strengths as to not spread yourself too thin), and while initial enemy placement is pre-determined you'll find out that they respawn with alarming frequency in random numbers and placements to constantly keep you on your toes. The game is not perfect, mind, and has some flaws. Most notable are the level designs for the final areas of the game don't seem quite as well designed as the rest of the game and some other small nitpicks, but these are minor gaffes in System Shock 2's excellent imageand are easily forgiven. If you like science fiction, survival horror, cyberpunk, body or eldritch horror, free form RPGs, first person shooters, adventure games, or any combination thereof of them, then System Shock 2 is well deserving of your attention. And hell, even if you don't like any of that stuff, it may be worth looking into just to try new things! You might just find yourself surprised.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2013
												I've had this review sitting up here mostly as a joke, but with the advent of us finally getting a true System Shock 1 Remake (that I've backed, hehe) I figured I'd rewrite my review to fully reflect my thoughts on one of my all time favorite games and a game I consider a masterpiece of western game development.The game's story is familiar enough, you're a soldier with amnesia who wakes up aboard a space ship where everything is royally screwed and you're contacted by a particularly angry woman who nags you to complete various tasks in order to undo the chaos that an apparent alien infestation has wrought. It may all seem very blasé at first but once you get about 1/3rd of the way into the game, you'll discover a really shocking (ayyy) plot twist that you won't see coming unless you've played Bioshock before this. But in addition to the game's main plot, you'll also discover audio logs off the beaten path that you can listen to that provide insights, backstory and tension from various deceased crew members that range from a greedy CEO who gradually turns from his precious money to fully embracing the horrors onboard the ship, to a couple who were more or less told to get a room and ended up getting an escape pod outta Dodge. It all really comes together to make the Von Braun feel like it was once a real place and it establishes a sense of humanity the place and makes the scenario all the more depressing and scary.Now while this is all fine and good, a game like this wouldn't be great without some kickass gameplay, and this game certainly delivers on all fronts. This is a really, really unique game that manages to combine Survival Horror, Old 90's esque FPS Gameplay and Deus ex styled RPG mechanichs into one delicious, although admittedly convoluted slurry that is incredibly satisfying to play through. Before you start the real game you're given a choice of a starting classes, the 'rooty tooty point and shooty' Marine, the xxxMLGPR0xxx techie, and the turbonerd Psionic who serves more or less as the game's mage and you get to pick what your starting skills are, starting with basic RPG stuff (movement speed, HP, inventory space, mana, ect) such as being able to hack various electronics on board the ship to provide you with more resources or modifying your guns to be more effective. No matter what you pick here though, you're free to build your character however you want throughout the game, so if you wanted to be a squishy wizard who wants to carry around the game's equivalent of a BFG 9000, you can. To further expand this, there's also perk stations that can sparsely be found on the ship to further specialize your build, giving this game massive ammounts of replayability that I've unfortunately been unable to find in many other games.On the topic of guns (admit it, we all play fps games to shoot the♥♥♥♥♥♥outta stuff), there's 4 weapons trees available, Standard, Energy, Heavy and Exotic. Standard is the one most people will start with and probably roll through many playthrus, as it has a Pistol, a shotgun and an assault rifle to you while also increasing the effectiveness of your starting wrench. Energy consists of weapons like the Energy pistol, the Laser Rapier, and the EMP rifle, which are typically more effective against robotic targets but have essentially unlimited ammo thru recharge stations to compensate. Heavy is an odd class as the Grenade launcher you get is the most powerful raw damage weapon in the game, while the BFG9000 you get at the very tailend of your progression is comparable to standard's Shotgun in terms of usefulness with the middle weapon being a useless Freeze ray. Exotic is almost the opposite of Energy, with it's weapons being more effective versus flesh targets and use the alien worm puddles as ammo but is made different by having the best melee in the game. It's really fun to experiment with all the weapons in the game, especially since the game discourages you from using one or two types of weapons at a time.With all the technical stuff aside, the actual gameplay is really tense. When you move throughout the ship it becomes more and more apparent that you're one of, if not the only survivor, with mangled corpses littered around that really add to the terrifying atmosphere of the game. This is complemented by some legitimately disturbing enemy design, as the main 'grunt' type enemies are ex-crewmembers who have been corrupted by the hivemind known as "The Many" and the results are completely visual. Their great sound design adds to the tension as you'll be hearing these guys calling you to reveal yourself before you see them, and it just gets all the more terrible when you start fighting them only for their humanity to break through and beg you to end their suffering. Add in the fact that ammo is so scarce at times that it will force you into beating stuff over the head with the melee of your choice or just leaving these things alive and roaming and you've got the perfect recipe for a butt-clenchingly tense game that makes you think about every action that you perform. Graphically, the game needs to be adressed. For 1999's standards it looks ok but it really does look like hot garbo now, so unless you're a weirdo like me and like these retro graphics, you'll want to seek out the fantastic community mods like SHTUP or Rebirth that make the game look all the nicer, and alot creepier too. Even then, the game can look really dated, but if you're the type to put gameplay over graphics this shouldn't matter.I really want to stress that this game has **SO** much replay value. This is a game that I do at least a yearly 'binge gaming' session, ususally consisting of at least 2 play throughs of the base game and then messing around on one of the game's unforunately few fan maps, but each playthrough can be entirely different based on how you choose your progression. I got into Shock 2 in around late 2009-ish and I'm still enjoying the game like I did when I was 13. This game is just THAT good.I'm really happy that System Shock is being remade, because System shock is a series that deserves your attention, though Specifically System Shock 2. This is a game that despite some of it's more oldschool mechanics feels incredibly fresh and polished even today. If you liked Bioshock at all and haven't played this yet, I suggest you do yourself a favor and pick this game up. I'm of the opinion that this game is a masterpiece that belongs in the ranks of LoZ OoT and MGS4 as being one of the greatest games of all time.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2013
												I've always thought horror was difficult, if not impossible, to convey in video games, especially when given the tools to fight back.I was wrong.You are alone. Resources are scarce. Everything is out to kill you. And it will.The atmosphere of this game is oppressing, each second as stressful as the previous one, the ship is a convoluted maze filled with terror.Although it has a few flaws, the story is wonderful, filled with tension and ambiguosity, as you are stuck between SHODAN and The Many, left wondering which of them is the lesser evil.SHODAN herself definitely earns a place in the pantheon of video game antagonists, not only using deception but also constantly belittling any effort on your part.As for the gameplay, it's surprisingly advanced for its time, and might seem overwhelmingly complex on your fist run. If you are expecting a shooter, you will probably find it clunky and frustrating, as this game is most definitely a RPG and has all the mechanics of one.Also worthy of note, the world is fully backtrackable and the level design is incredible, state-of-the-art late 90s fare, albeit falling a bit short towards the end.A landmark in the scene and a source of inspiration for many others to come, especially the Deus Ex and BioShock franchises, both created by former Looking Glass employees.I would highly recommend this game to anyone interested in PC gaming history, make sure to play it on the impossible difficulty setting, which will give you a real challenge and enhance the thick, lingering atmosphere and sense of dread.

												I bought this game in 1999 back when I was 11 years old, though I finally got the stones to fully make my way through the game when I was 17. I quit the game from fright several times, but kept coming back because I was determined to beat the terrors of the Von Braun. Since then I have returned to the game many times just so I could soak in the atmosphere of the game and face the evils from Tau Ceti V once again.System Shock 2 is a cyberpunk first person shooter with a good chunk of RPG elements. Elements such as inventory management, stats and different builds, and choices that affect your progress forward. There are also a survival aspect, it becoming more pronounced on the higher difficulties as combat gets deadlier.Several games have since then used similar themes and elements to great effect, so what makes this old timer so great? In my opinion it is the dread that the game instills in you, I haven't quite found a game that did it in a similar or quite as effective fashion. The player starts the game on the Von Braun some time after it has gone to hell and the Many has control. You end up feeling utterly alone on the Von Braun, light-years away from any semblance of help, while being sought out by the grotesque minions of The Many. You run around chasing your only lifeline and voice of reason in this whole mess, while wading through the sludge that used to be the crew of this ship only to sink deeper with every step. I remember feeling utterly crushed several times with the relevation that my struggles had only brought me more terrors to face.It is a superb game, but it is not without flaws. The latter part of the game gets less and less refined, most visible in the level design. As the game progresses the areas seem to get less and less polished, which is a shame as the details helpes alot with the atmosphere that makes this game great.  The Von Braun is largely well made for its time, but the Rickenbacker is bland, uninspiring and seems like it was rushed. The last stages of the game has some quite exotic themes and the technology of the time was perhaps not well suited for something as ambitious as these areas.Despite that, I recommend this game to everyone looking for a classic Survial Horror game.

Posted: March 23, 2015
												This game needs no introduction. It's regarded as one of the best games for PC ever made, as well as one of the best for its genre... and it is wholly deserving of all its praise. System Shock 2 is a game that defies any real review, to do so would to really spoil the experience. It needs to be played to understand why it is so good, and that is what playing it is: an experience.The game is a rare example of design, gameplay, aesthetic, atmosphere, and presentation all working in near perfect harmony to deliver an engrossing experience that pulls you in and keeps you going until the final hours are passed. The RPG elements are almost completely free form, allowing you to build your character in almost any way you like focusing on what you want as you want it (though in the early game you'll do well to focus on your initial strengths as to not spread yourself too thin), and while initial enemy placement is pre-determined you'll find out that they respawn with alarming frequency in random numbers and placements to constantly keep you on your toes. The game is not perfect, mind, and has some flaws. Most notable are the level designs for the final areas of the game don't seem quite as well designed as the rest of the game and some other small nitpicks, but these are minor gaffes in System Shock 2's excellent imageand are easily forgiven. If you like science fiction, survival horror, cyberpunk, body or eldritch horror, free form RPGs, first person shooters, adventure games, or any combination thereof of them, then System Shock 2 is well deserving of your attention. And hell, even if you don't like any of that stuff, it may be worth looking into just to try new things! You might just find yourself surprised.

												I played this for the first time in 2015, and it is still a fantastic game, even without nostalgia. The gameplay and AI are dated, and I would recommend looking for some graphics mods, but even after 16 years this is one of the better games that I've played. Firstly, the atmosphere in this game is incredible. I could only play in 30-minute spurts for the first few levels, because the game really creeped me out. The audio and sound effects in this game are great and help set the mood. If you've played bioshock(if you haven't you really should), this game is very similar, although it's also a lot scarier than bioshock. After some time playing, you start to get a little used to the constant feeling of fear, but as you progress you encounter more things that are even more unsettling. The audio logs added pieces of the story together as you collect them, and make you wonder what the hell happened on this ship. The atmosphere and story sucks you in, it's so good.Once you get used to the horror aspects of the game, you start to actually figure out how the game works. This game has a ridiculous amount of customization for you to choose from, but like the rest of the game you are limited in your resources and skill points(called cyber modules). I started out putting points into PSI and ended up using a lightsaber halfway through, using PSI to buff/amplify my melee skills. There are so many ways you can play, and I can easily see this game having a lot of replay value because of it. And without spoiling anything, the story is great. TL:DR - Fantastic game, 9/10 mostly because it is a little datedPROS-Amazing atmosphere-Great use of audio-Interesting story-Expansive and fun skill system, customizable-Great setting-SHODANCONS-Dated controls(fixable), UI takes a little bit to get used to-Mods make graphics pretty good, but some things like enemy models are still ugly(not a big deal though)- last minute or so is meh, was expecting an amazing ending after the rest of the game.Great game, highly recommend. This is almost a must play if you liked bioshock, because this game did almost everything bioshock did except earlier (though both games are great).

												Damn good game.  The character graphics are a little dated, but the environment itself has aged spectacularly.  SHODAN is particularly memorable and the game hits a nice mix of horror, difficulty, and survivability.  There's a lot of the Bioshock series' gameplay in this (for those of you who played those before this), which makes sense since the people who made System Shock 2 went on to create the BIoshock games.  Some gore, but most of the horror will come from realizing that you have a particularly powerful enemy around the corner coming after you, and you just ran out of bullets.  Good luck!SS2 isn't easy, and it definitely is the kind of game where a screwup early on can indeed wreck your game later on.  It's perfectly possible to find yourself in a nearly unwinnable situation - don't waste ammunition, be sure to pick up ammo from everywhere you can, and learn to love the melee weapons.All in all, well worth the purchase price, and a classic.

content:
Posted: May 7, 2015
												System Shock 2 is the grandfather of modern FPS shooters. Despite it being quite underrated, System Shock 2 was the influence behind games like Bioshock and Half-Life. It is a dark and gritty game that combines a dark and scary atmosphere with surprisingly enjoyable exploration, crafting and research. As far as the story goes, you start out as a recruit and get to select your main path of game style. You have the Marines which will eventually allow you to get your hands on weapons ranging from pistols to grenade launchers and EMP rifles. You have the Navy, the "tech" class which makes it easier to hack machines and security systems. The last path is the OSA, which specialises in 'psi-powers' which allow you to use your mind to attack enemies, move items and objects from a distance and disable cameras. Afterwards, you are given a selection of three 'subpaths' which give you points in specific skills. Afterwards, you can level up your skills using cybermodules which are generally given to you as a reward for completing missions but you may find them in the world. Players are not restricted to the class they chose e.g those who picked the Marine path can invest their cybermodules in PSI powers. While a "jack of all trades" approach is tempting, it is best to stick to your chosen path because you may find it become incredibly expensive to maintain skill trees at the same time. When you're finished, the game begins. You find yourself onboard the Von Braun, a ship which has succumbed to a strange infection. All hell has broken loose and you must save yourself from the hybrids and other alien lifeforms, and from the psychotic Artificial Intelligence known as XERXES.The player can paint a picture of what happened to the Von Braun through collectibles, which are often recordings made by other crew members. Much like in Bioshock, they also may contain important passcodes and give away locations of important items. Through this method, following the story is optional and all those simply wanting to beat the game do not have to concentrate while a NPC goes on and on. (In this game, the only NPCs who talk to you are SHODAN and whatshernameagain.)System Shock 2 has some of the best level design I've ever seen, and some of the worst. Backtracking is one of the biggest issues this game has. While the levels are big and non-linear allowing for player freedom, they encourage backtracking. As you continue through the game, you are able to explore the Von Braun fully. An elevator located on every floor of the Von Braun allows you to return to an already explored floor (for the purposes of research, farming, healing etc.) What makes the level design superb is that it gives the player not only a sense of discovery and exploration, it also gives the player a sense of confusion and being lost. Some levels contain branches where you have to explore them, find an item and return to the main "hub" part to accomplish a mission to progress further. This does often lead to a sense of misdirection. This is something System Shock 2 does good. That being said, some levels basically have major chokeholds which don't allow the player to use different strategies if an enemy is blocking them. Every level contains security cameras monitored by the rogue AI XERXES. If it spots you, it will activate a security alarm which essentially sends a horde of enemies at you. It is always vital to watch your surroundings. Combat wise, the game offers a large arsenal of weaponry. Guns, grenade launchers, sabres and many more. Of course most weapons require a specific level in that particular skill line (e.g EMP Rifle requires an energy skill of 6.) As I mentioned earlier, the player is given the freedom to invest in the weapons skill tree even if they picked the Navy or OSA. Every weapon is degradable and you have to repair it if it becomes broken. While this degradable feature does make it substantially difficult for the player if they don't monitor their weapon's level of quality, it can be a bit annoying at times. The player can also modify their weapons using the modify skill, which basically increases the stats of that particular weapon. Combat aside, another unique feature of System Shock 2 is Research. On your journey, you may come across an item that is 'unresearched.' To research it, you require a table, and the required chemicals. To get these chemicals, you have to go to a chemical storeroom, which are located in almost every map. However, each chemical storeroom is not identical and you may to have to explore until you find the storeroom with the chemical you need. Upon researching an item, it will tell you what it does. For instance, some enemies may drop one of these items. If researched, it gives you a % damage boost against that particular enemy. While researching objects is an optional feature. It is best to invest in researching, as enemies later on do become difficult and the boost would help.Present in System Shock 2 is a hacking system, where you have to click on squares to create a line. Hacking is used to open crates, hack machines and disable security systems as well as terminating security alarms. System Shock 2 also offers a variety of enemies, ranging from psychic monkeys to annelid spiders and giant robots. As the game progresses, you have to face a growing variety of enemies. It does get incredibly difficult later on. Each encounter with enemies rests on the path you have chosen before. Marines can simply charge in, wreck the enemy and let that be the end of that. A Navyman can backtrack and find a way to avoid the enemy, and a OSA can use their PSI powers to stealthy kill the enemy. Enemies are generally randomly placed on the map, (apart from some pre-set robots.)Levels are not saturated in enemies, and there are times when the map can be empty. This gives the player plenty of freedom to explore, and makes each encounter with enemies unique. As the player progresses, enemy difficulty increases substantially. This difficulty can be eventually lowered through research. It does not matter what weapons you have, you will always be underpowered. You have to be incredibly observant of your surroundings, and this is something that System Shock 2 does very well.Present in this game is a co-op mode, which allows you to play with two other people! I strongly recommend that you finish System Shock 2 solo before playing co-op, because playing with a partner is a different experience. Knowing that you have backup deducts from the game's overall atmosphere. Co-op, although it is generally stable and bugfree, does contain some issues. (Not surprising for a game made in 1999.) I have encountered some bugs and glitches such as: unnoticable lag where automatic doors open for the host and not for the other players. The elevator can get stuck and won't change the level essentially trapping you (this can be fixed by all players restarting the game.) Enemies can [rarely] get stuck in their default model (aka 'mingebag' ) position and not do anything apart from making noise. A friend and I also encountered a glitch where NPCs would spawn in places they're not supposed to be. (We encountered some live crew member NPCs on one of the decks.) If playing co-op, i would save right before the SHODAN room (Most glitches tended to start after this scene in my case.) Apart from this, Co-op is fun to play with friends.On one final note, the atmosphere in this game is excellent in making the player feel weak and underpowered. While the game's music is topnotch quality, it doesn't always fit in with the feel of the game. Regardless, the dark, gritty and scary environments keep the player awake and observant. Just remember to keep in mind that this game was made in 1999 as the graphics have not aged well.System Shock 2 is a must-play for Halflife and Bioshock fans. It combines a range of unique aspects and abilities. it is an underrated yet enjoyable experience.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2016
												Wow. What to say about this game? Basically, if you like Bioshock, you'll almost certainly like this. It has a lot of similarities in mechanics, with hacking, machines to buy ammo and items, big maps, lot of different kinds of quests you're set on, psychic powers plus weapons, recordings to listen to with door codes and hints and things, etc. But System Shock is FAR more brutal, and I was playing on easy. Be prepared to be always out of ammo, currency, health, inventory space and regen points. Yet, it's really, really, really, REALLY good. It's got depth out to wazoo, and tons of cool features and a bajillion ways to play. There's three major "career choices"--either being a skill monkey (hacking, repairing, etc), straight-up shooter (lots of powerful weapons), and psi (basically magic, with fire, invisibility, telekinesis, etc.) You make the choice at the very beginning and there's not a lot of explanation before you pick, so do a little research online first to find the best fit for your playstyle. Let's break it down to the basics:Pros:+Great variety of tasks. It's an FPS, but there's lots of "puzzles". Things like "go to this place and turn on this button." But then there's something that's gone wrong, so now you need to go here and find the problem first, then do this other things, and then you can hit the button. You have to deal with radiation and toxins, can hack things, repair your equipment as it wears down, research items you find, etc.+Tons of upgrades. Four different main upgrade trees: ability stats (strength, agility, etc), psi powers, weapon proficiency (energy, standard, heavy, etc), and skills (hacking, repairing, etc.)+Never a dull moment.+Huge map, with tons of different areas and problems to deal with. It really made you feel like you were on a ship, with a medical/science deck, engineering deck, command, recreation, bridge/operations, etc. You could go back to anywhere anytime. There's only one point where you can never completely retrace your steps.Neutral:~It's an old game, so it's polygon count is super low. Expect characters with point heads, cloned textures on the wall, and all around poor graphics. I didn't mind it, because I'm a fan of old games, but it shows its age graphically, which might bother some people.~ There's a research function that's kind of neat, but also frustrating. You can find objects or organs from enemies to research, and they give you bonuses against them or the ability to use those organs as med kits or psi boosters or weapons. However, it's frustrating because most of the research requires chemicals, which you can't just carry arround because space is at a premium and you never know what chemicals you're going to need later. So you end up having to backtrack a loooooong way just to find the storeroom with the chemicals so you can get that ONE chemical you need. Frustrating, but it's really a neat mechanic in general, so I'm putting it as neutral.Cons:-The map is crap. There are little icons telling you where things are, like regeneration points, item purchasing, etc, but the icons are the same color as the map lines, so they're unreadable half the time because you can't tell whether it's a C or S or whatever letter you're trying to find. The low res doesn't help, either. Also, each deck of the ship you're on has different sections, which 1) don't show up on the map until you've been there (understandable), and 2) won't be available to look at when you're in a different section of the ship, even if you HAVE already been there. So trying to find that one place you were at two hours ago that you need to find again is really hard. All together, I probably did about 2-3 hours of wandering in about 30 hours of gameplay. I'm not even exaggerating. I could spend 45 minutes just trying to find a storeroom I'd been looking for.- There's not a lot of handholding or explanation. There's "enough" for most things, but there's no indication of what early play will be like when you're picking your career path. I started off psi because it sounded the most interesting, only to find out it's basically hard mode, since when you run out of psi points (i.e. mana) you have to resort to other weapons or melee, but your physical stats suck. I ended up restarting as the hacker archetype and made sure to up my weapon use and fared much better. Also, I didn't know when I went to a different deck of the ship that I could go back again. It may be that I'm used to modern games that prevent you from returning to earlier maps (sometimes warning you in advance that you're leaving an area in case you wanted to go back for some reason). But you're on a space ship, and you've got full run of the ship. Which meant I was wandering around, desperate for them to give me a vending machine or a heal or something, never knowing I could go back downstairs to the ones I had already been too. I didn't figure that out on my own until about 5 hours in or so.- The game is extremely stingy when it comes to weapons, ammo, inventory space, etc. Your weapons take up space in your inventory that could be used for other items, so it's not like the typical "carrying around 8 weapons" situation you have in a lot of FPS games. You have to decide very carefully and commit to using certain weapons or be prepared to switch when you run out of ammo.- The "currency" of the game is used for hacking AND modifying weapons AND buying things at vending machines, so if you're hacking all the time, you might never have enough to buy bullets. The drop rate of currency itself is also pretty stingy. Most enemies drop no money (frequent), ~25 (decent but infrequent), or 5 (common). But it might take anywhere from 1-5 bullets to take down a single enemy to get that 5 money, and a set of 6 bullets can cost 85!!!! You'll burn through bullets (and thus money) faster than you'll ever get it from enemies. Hacking helps a lot, because it can get you into locked boxes with a nice stash of 25-75 money, but you'll probably burn 20 on a tough hack and 3 on an easy hack, so it's a gamble.- There's a point of no return before the final boss, but I ended up expending all of my ammo trying to beat the mooks before it so I ended up with no health and very little ammo before the big boss with no way to go back and restock because I had been saving my game in the same save slot. My only saving grace was the implant I had found that regenerates 1 point of health at a rate of 1/30 seconds. I had to let the game idle for about an hour while I let my health regen, then had to do the same evil run through the gauntlet of baddies that took all my ammo last time, but I had to do a PERFECT run or I wouldn't have enough ammo to actually kill the final boss. After ALL that, there's a whole other area with ANOTHER boss to beat, and I got ZERO ammo before it. Ick. Not fair. And that was on easy difficulty.-They give you respawn points, but you have to activate them before you can use them. If you haven't found the one in the new area you've just entered, you don't respawn, you just die. And if you don't have a recent save point, god help you. I was saving after LITERALLY every fight and LITERALLY ever time I found a new item or healed or whatever. It was about every 5 seconds because having to redo even 5 minutes of work is super frustrating. Also, you only come back at 25 health each time, so recovering from death is very, very difficult.-Healing. Wow. Super inefficient. There are healing beds (that cost money) scattered around, but except for maybe one, you can't just use them right away. You have to find a key that unlocks them. Which means that you might have been at 25 health for a LONG time, and you FINALLY find a healing bed that will get you back up to full health....and you can't use it.tl;dr Play this game. Be prepared for a lot of hair pulling, lacking everything you need/want, but if you like difficulty, depth and variety, this is your game.

												I did not play System Shock 2 until 2014, and have never played its namesake.System Shock 2 is not a good FPS. It was never designed to be a great FPS. It is an old game that shows many signs of age. The textures are dated. The models are dated.It is an old game.What then, makes me recommend System Shock 2? What is its relevance along technically advanced games of more modern times? It is the marriage of forgettable FPS and engaging RPG mechanics that surprise me. It is the interesting characters and fleshed out backstory that make me want to see it through. It is the complex level designs that show me attention to detail. All of these elements are reason why I review the title positively. SS2 was made before its time and yet its creation still influences games today. It is an important part of gaming as a whole and deserves to be looked at. If you can see past the age and the odd hitch, pick System Shock 2 up, tweak the controls, slap on a texture mod, and experience SHODAN.Please Consider: There are no mission arrows. The map can be unhelpful. Codes from audio logs must be typed manually.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												What is it with Sci Fi Horror set in space and Hydroponics deck being the most terrifying thing in the entire game? I don't know how, but this game, despite the fact that it hasn't aged well at all in the graphics department, creates such an amazing atmosphere and really sets the tone in an exemplary way. You play a guy with absolutely no fashion sense (jumpsuit and cybernetically implanted goggles make him look like Adam Jensen going through his goth phase) on his quest to find out just what went wrong on the Von Braun, which has seemingly been taken over by worm people and overly friendly robots who blow up in your face, spoiler alert. Despite the sometimes dodgy voice acting and the pretty awful movement controls (in my opinion, but then again almost all games from this period controlled like♥♥♥♥♥♥, this game is a great RPG, and one of the few in recent memory that has a fairly rich and detailed mythos embedded into the game itself. We don't get enough good Sci-Fi/Cyberpunk Action RPG's, in my opinion, and despite the fact that this is a precursor to this genre, it is still one of the best in terms of atmosphere, story and world building. I heartily reccomend this game to any fans of the genre. Speaking as a person who doesn't have nostalgia goggles on (many people seem to in the review section, and with good reason), I can safely say that this game still holds up in quite a few respects all these years on. Notstalgia usually makes people think of something that may have been ok-ish as the best thing since sliced bread, but what happens when it is something truly great for its time?

												I'll start with the things this game got wrong. Most games like this with skill trees/points in particular are bad about forcing you to min-max and this one is no exception. If anything it's worse than most other games from the same era cause you can literally make the game un-winnable if you don't know what stats you need and don't. The limitations of the engine create a crushing sense of isolation and the only contact you have being with entities that cannot be trusted further add to the lingering sense of dread.Flaws and all, this is still a game worth experiencing. Definitely worth checking out.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2016
												If you haven't heard of System Shock 2, well, it's the game that was so gripping and fantastic that it secretly got remade as another gripping and fantastic game, Bioshock.Now this game, System Shock 2, it's a doozy. I could recommend it solely because of the atmosphere it drapes over you. It's the only game I've played that actually reached in through my eye sockets, curled its wires around my spine, and really, truly made me feel powerless. Imagine, if you can, my situation. I am trapped, trapped inside the twisting bowels of a vast machine, with just a little space to move around. And the more I move around, the more I realize, I am tangled in two machines - one of flesh, the other of hissing steel. A voice is guiding me, helping me, but it's just a voice. And as I wrench myself free from deep within this machine, violently stumbling out of the clutches of one chamber and into another, always the steel is watching from my front, and the flesh is grabbing at my heels.I am never allowed to forget that between my scampering body and the dead vacuum of space lies a thin layer of aluminium and glass.This game is not a cake-walk - it's a tough journey and a tough experience. If you like horror, you HAVE TO experience System Shock 2, the acme of the genre. There are a few brilliant moments in the game that made my brain drop whatever it was doing and just kind of kick and whimper. I recall saying things like "Ga! It can't, wait, how? Oh hell, what?? No!" (And I'm a pretty jaded guy.) Some of these moments are big, others are small enough to miss for a while - and then, when they do hit, they hit really, really hard. It's just brilliant, singularly brilliant.Even with the horror that is the graphical technology of 1999, the visuals in SS2 do a fantastic job. The NPC models are blurry by today's standards, but somehow so disturbing that they never lose their impact. The dying spaceship you're on is a masterpiece of design: corpses and debris are meaningfully scattered, each piece telling an aching story. The stellar sound design (by far, by far, the best I've encountered in any game) begs to be experienced. A sprawling RPG skillset and intrigueing sets of tools and weapons let you survive in any number of ways, all of them challenging.I recommend playing the original System Shock first (the enhanced edition with all the sounds); it's not essential, but will give you a little more context and back-story. It is definitely worth playing just to experience the first chapter of what I think is the best villain in a video game. SS2 does a great job of painting the full picture, though.I could host a week-long seminar about the great things this game achieves, but the truth is, you should simply experience it for yourself. Get the game now, and try to play it as coninuously as you can to avoid fragmenting the experience.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												As one of the all time survival horror classics, System Shock 2 has been on the top of my to-do list for a while.  Now that I've finally finished the game I've been telling myself to play since 2007, here's my thoughts:Story: The story was very well done, and it shows how much it's influenced future games of its type, like Bioshock and Dead Space.  The basics are simple enough: you wake up on board a starship with amnesia, and someone starts barking orders into your ear while you're attacked by mutants with wrenches.  Not the most inspired start by today's standards, but what really gets the story moving are logs from other people on the ship.  These recording from before and during the attack build a large world around you (as large as you can get on a spaceship), with other characters carrying out their own subplots around you.  Some of the lines can be a bit narmy, but it's kind of saddening when you find a log from a character you've been hearing of for the past couple levels, only for it to be a recording of their last moments.The active plot is wonderful as well.  SHODAN being the main villian has been spoiled since the original box art in 1999, but the build up to the reveal is quite well done, both in story and atmosphere.  The story about The Many is superb as well, and everything is wrapped up in a satisfying ending.  That's not counting the final boss fight, of course, but I'll get to that in a minute.All in all, there's nothing to complain about here.  A very well told story from start to finish.Sound: I'll split this section off into a couple different sections.  The overall sound direction is great: there's a lot of little ambient sounds that add to the atmosphere, and hearing security bots and mutants in the distance makes the game feel very tense.  You'll get a couple jumpscares, too, with unexpected explosions here and there as the ship degrades.The actual music in the game is excellent, but some of it doesn't quite fit for it.  On the very first level Med/Sci, you're treated to an energetic techo beat that seems more conductive to running & gunning, like something out of Unreal Tournament.  But, at that point, all you have to your name is a wrench and (maybe) low level Psi powers, so a run & gun style is just going to get your head bashed in with a pipe wrench.  It gets much better after that, however, with tracks that really keep you on edge.The voice acting is, to put it nicely, really over the place.  The lead character is mute (save for 1 line at the end of the game), so all of the voice work is done by the supporting characters.  SHODAN and The Many sound great, with SHODAN being a standout performance.  Some of the enemies (like the mutant hybrids) are good, too, and can cause some jump scares hearing their distorted voices coming up fast behind you.  The rest of the cast and logs range from "great" to "hobo they pulled off the street, and are paying with vodka & cigarettes".  Some of the voice acting just...wasn't convincing at all.Graphics: I won't touch too much on the graphics, considering the age of the game.  It looks great for the time it came out in, looking a lot like Half Life, Thief and the above mentioned Unreal.  The level design was outstanding as well: I never found myself getting lost, and the setup of the ship makes as much sense as a starship would make.  A special note goes to the final two levels of the game in terms of level design, but I don't want to spoil to much here.  Gameplay: the gameplay is just as polarizing as the sound direction is.  The core gameplay is a pretty functional FPS, with some platforming in a few places.  There's some RPG elements in the form of 'Cyber Modules' that you earn by completing plot related objectives, as well as by looking in some hard to reach places.  These Cyber Modules can be used to upgrade profeciency with weapons and tech related things (such as Repair and Hacking), increase your base stats, or unlock psionic abilities.  It's a pretty neat twist to the Fighter-Mage-Thief setup that many RPG's use.  The game gives you a lot to choose from, and no two characters are going to have the same build (unless you're reading from a guide or something).However, these same RPG elements are one of the core failings of the game.  The above mentioned weapons you can train in are horribly imbalanced: some weapon classes are much better than the others, and picking the wrong build (or running out of specific ammo near the end) can render the game completely unwinnable.  It's especially apparent in the final levels of the game: the second to last level renders an entire set of weapons useless, while the final level renders another set of weapons (one that was good against the enemies in the previous level) equally worthless.  If you relied on only one of these sets of weapons during the game, then time to restart!  This is more likely to happen on Impossible difficulty, however: Easy and Normal give you more than enough modules to modify your build if you notice anything wrong, and even Hard is pretty generous with them once you're on deck 3/4.The RPG elements also add some replay value to the game.  While I completed the game with a lot of Tech and Standard Weapons training, I may do a 2nd playthrough as a completely Psionic character next.  The difficulty also spikes the higher you go, and I'm honestly dreading trying up the game on Impossible.Overall: An extremely well told story and some legitimate scares, woven into a functional yet flawed FPSRPG.  If you're considering this game, the biggest question to ask yourself is this: can you stomach 'meh' gameplay for a great story?  If so, I highly recommend this game.  But, I can freely admit it's not everyone: feel free to stay away if you're not into survival horror games, or if you like your FPS's feeling a bit less 'broken'.
