Posted: June 25, 2015
												Finished the game at exactly 25 hours, but it was a jam-packed 25 hours.The ending was terrible, but other than that, this game is great! Bioshock was good, but System Shock 2, despite being 8 years earlier, is so much better. It's short enough to play a second time, and you might want to, as the story keeps you on your toes and there are at least 4 different experiences of the gameplay to have, since you have total control over your character's stats and proficiencies... and they matter!Some people complain about difficulty, but I've found it pretty reasonable even on hard, just expect that you WILL die... save often as there's not really an auto-quicksave, and try to conserve your ammo. It's not like Resident Evil in terms of ammo scarcity, the game is pretty generous in resources, but you don't want to run out all the same. It's an RPG, so choose your skills wisely and you'll be fine.Be warned; Since the game is set on a large spaceship where areas become unlocked as you progress, there can be a lot of backtracking to get certain items that are only found on a previous deck. There's a mod that reduces the amount of enemy respawns that happen, which I found made the game a lot more enjoyable, so consider using that if you're getting ticked off with clearing the same areas out over and over. Another good mod is one that increases the durability of weapons, since on default they tend to break just a little too much for my liking.Either way, the game is best enjoyed when modded to update its graphics and fix bugs. Just follow  this guide  and remember to set up your controls as the default ones are terrible.Also, I want to be the first to say: Prefontaine is very clearly Richard Dawkins. I'm really surprised this wasn't said at some point since the game's release. He talks about the biology and evolution of the creatures and looks exactly like one of Dawkin's Photos. Same haircut and neutral frown.

Posted: August 2, 2013
												There is no need for me to recommend System Shock 2 - it is an experience every  gamer should make. There are already many praises of atmosphere and gameplay out there, so I thought I just share some memories of my three playthroughs.There have been years between each single one, the first shortly after its release in late 1999, the second one a few years later and the final one I just finished recently. But every time I had a vastly different gaming experience, as if I played three games instead of the same. I still remember how I got SS2, because it was an impulse buy during a trip to the UK. I played what I always felt was the definite way - a Navy Hacker focussed on stealth who avoided most fights after I learned early on that fighting without skills is bad. I got so many ressources that I had to make the med bay my personal storage room. But this way I had enough Anti Personal Ammo that I even enjoyed the later parts of the game.My second encounter with the game was as a Marine shooting himself through the Van Braun.  The game was easier, but less open crates meant less ammunition and I remember running away from spiders and rumblers because I had only my wrench left - until I found more explosives!O.S.A. psyops always intimidated me because I thought there were not enough Cybernetic Moduls to get core abilities plus psy ones. While true, you do not need many skills like repair at all when you can make yourself invisible or turn the enemies against themselves. And you can be a master of the melee combat through stacking temporary buffs which is rewarding and saves ammo.Three different playthroughs, three vastly different playstyles, one game: play Shock2! (it even looks ok with mods, I promise)

Posted: December 19, 2015
												If you like Bioshock and haven't played this, you absolutely should. Great mechanics, a more complex story, and a general vibe that somewhere, something went wrong. The game trusts you to figure out things  on your own, and feels more immersive because of it. Example: at one point, you have to find a computer chip to access a certain area. Instead of "objective complete: found chip," you have to sprint to the storage area where electronics are located, reference the chip model number in your email, and find the correct model of chip before continuing. When you want to use a door keycode, you'll be checking your PDA for the code, and keeping your head on a swivel while you punch in the numbers, all while Shodan goads you like a glitchy/vindictive GlaDOS. Like the original Half-Life, there's something about the gameplay that's addicting and massively fun. Btw, if  you're worried about "nostaliga goggles," I played this for the first time last year, and it still holds up.One quick con, though: the game allows you to upgrade what you want, even if it leads to failure. Hacking and radiation resistance is highly recommended.

Posted: December 30, 2015
												Easily one of the best games I have ever had the privilege of playing. It is truly a masterful work that really gets inside your head and endlessly messes with you. It's probably the only video game I have ever played that was able to retain its degree of horror despite how dated it looks, as your mind seems to fill in whatever blanks are created from the lack of graphical quality. Its atmosphere and dark themes end up seriously getting to you, and you'll find yourself anxiously checking every corner at the sound of an enemy or freaking out whenever a security camera goes off. The only real low points of the game (aside from how dated it may seem to some) are the controls. They're somewhat convoluted and take some getting used to. There is also much rebinding to do upon first launch (A and D are bound to turn instead of strafe and X is bound to backing up instead of S). But despite this, the controls are totally possible (and totally worth) getting used to. All in all, this is a game that I recommend to absolutely everyone. Even if you are not a fan of retro PC gaming or find yourself cringing at anything that seems too outdated, this game is easily worth getting.

												People often compare Bioshock with System Shock, calling Bioshock the predecessor of System Shock, but that's just bs. Maybe story wise the original Bioshock is on par, but gameplay wise System Shock 2 is far superior. Bioshock is more of a shooter while System Shock 2 is an RPG, there is so much more content in System Shock2 for you to explore, and the atmosphere so cold, making the title a combination of almost perfect story and gameplay. To be frank, the graphics of SyS2 might be a lil bit out dated but a real hardcore gamer shouldn't judge a game by its graphics, but its gameplay.Overall, the game was way ahead of its time and gameplay wise the depth it offers has surpassed even most, if not all of the modern titles. Bioshock Infinite is a joke when compared with SyS2, the only selling point of the former is that the plot is 'deep', but to me that's just artificial mind♥♥♥♥ery that appears to be deep, I have no idea why such a mediocre shooter could be so overhyped. tis really a shame that most modern gamers have never even heard of System Shock, and no more titles like this can be produced today even though the budgets of modern video games are much much larger.In short, ditch Bioshock Infinite and buy System Shock 2, try it and see for youself, you'll never want to go back, and become as cynical about the Bioshock series as I am.

												An oldie but a goodie!This game has you on your toes as you travel a ship infested with zombies, robots, and disgusting organic mutations. 												This game to me is an unmatched favorite. From an era where games might not have looked the best but sure as hell gave you a run for your money. It's got a strong storyline embeded in it's core, a bit of mystery, a lot of survival and of course what would be creepy creatures to run from or kill. Your choice per say. Everywhere you turn you could be facing an enemy if not careful. The game is usually forgiving depending on your play style. They advice what first time players should use and I agree with that advice. But for the more advanced they do have a slightly confusing psy system in place to test your wit. Stats and skill points through out the game to keep you improving for what seems like nothing compared to a perfect machine (shodan.) If you have the time and interest I would strongly agree to pick this game up. 												I finished it yesterday (on Easy, full disclosure) for the first time, and had never played or seen it played before, though I was VERY familiar with otehr Irrational games like Bioshock, etc. After repeatedly hearing this game's name in conjunction with the words"best of all time" I decided it merited a try.System Shock 2 is Bioshock's older, far more badass and brutal brother. I loved Bioshock, Bioshock 2, and to a slightly lesser extent Bioshock Inifinite, and I've gotta say, this 16 YEAR OLD game makes them all look like garbage.Scratch that, System Shock 2 makes just about every other game look like garbage.Letting alone the fact the this came out IN 19-♥♥♥♥ING-99, it has a brilliant, immersive story; great equipment and RPG elements, and is scary as all hell. The sole way in which this game shows it's age (aside from the graphics, which i'll discuss in a moment) is in its melee hitting. Sometimes hitting small monsters is kind of annoying. That's It. Aside from slighgtly dated graphics, which again,  were released in 1999, the game still looks pretty good, and after spending enough time on the Von Braun you'll stop noticing their dated look.This game does present one problem; after playing it to the end, the influence this game has had on every game that has followed it is STAGGERING, you will become infuriated as you realize your favorite franchises just copied System Shock 2 (inb4 its a sequel, nothing is original. Shut up), like, blatantly. And then the logical conclusion, which is far more infuriating, HOW HAS THERE NOT BEEN MORE GAMES OF THIS QUALITY THIS WHOLE ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ TIME?!?! NINETEEN ♥♥♥♥ING NINETY NINE FOR ♥♥♥♥S SAKE. If you haven't played it, finish reading this, then seriously, REALLY SERIOUSLY, buy it right ♥♥♥♥ing now and set out aboard the Von Braun. This game will fall into your favorite games of all time, and deserves all the praise and more it has ever received.

												This is an AMAZING game with a story that is vast and honestly more than I expected out of a 1999 video game. I had read that this game is the spiritual predecessor to Bioshock, and I can definately see resemblances here and there. It has a sort of RPG element, where you can raise your stats, weapon abilities, psionic powers, and skills such as hacking. There are no levels per se, but sections that you slowly gain access to.About the only faults I can say about the game is that towards the end, there is a lot of back-and-forth travelling you need to do, it's not always clear where you're supposed to go, and I did run into some slightly bad AI at times. It is an old game, so graphics might also be on the list of faults, but I honestly didn't care about the slightly improved 1999 look.Again, the story is amazing, it'll last you a long time if you look around like I did, and the environment was interesting. I only wish they'd remake the game with today's technology!

content:
Posted: April 16, 2015
												System Shock 2's legacy lives on partly with the existence of the Deus Ex and Bioshock franchises, but it is more than capable to stand on its own right even today. Despite its outdated controls, GUI and graphics, it trumps most modern titles in terms of atmosphere, immersion, gameplay and story. In fact, many of SS2's features have been integrated into modern games, most notably the presence of audio logs put in unlikely places.I would recommend taking your time with setting up the game. The standard controls are not good. You will most likely have to rebind your keys based on which weapons/items you choose to use throughout the game, there are so many that you won't get the chance to use them all effectively. The greatest issue I had with this game is that it uses an outdated control scheme for accessing your items. A row of quick access slots, like the one featured in the Deus Ex games, would've been much better for weapon/item access.Some of the map designs are confusing, and it can be easy to get lost in your first playthrough. Even worse, the game has a minimap function that is disabled by default. Make sure to enable it as soon as you can, it'll make your life much easier.Resources are scarce. You will be punished for wasting them. On the other hand, the game rewards you for exploration and careful observation. Many items will be placed out of reach or carefully hidden, take your time to find them as long as you aren't under fire.This game rewards carefulness over gung-ho, reckless charging into unknown areas. Play carefully, lean over corners, use stealth.You will most likely get frustrated at one point or another for the reasons above and many others, but trust me, this game is worth going all the way to the end. There aren't many games that can offer the experience that System Shock 2 provides nowadays.
